questions.text: A researcher isolates an immune cell from a blood sample. This cell initially produces IgM but, after being stimulated by a T-cell, can go on to produce other classes of antibodies. Which of the following surface proteins is most likely expressed by this cell?
questions.solution:
This researcher most likely identified a B-cell, which expresses the CD40 surface protein. After being activated, a B-cell initially produces IgM. However, once it interacts with a helper T-cell, the B-cell can undergo class switching and produce additional antibodies, including IgG, IgA, and IgE.  

The different cells of the immune system can be distinguished based on their surface proteins. A comparison of the proteins expressed by each cell type can be found below.  



Option Analysis

✅ CD40:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Glycoprotein IIb/IIIa:
Incorrect: Glycoprotein IIb/IIIa (GpIIb/IIIa) is an integrin complex found on the surface of platelets and plays an important role in promoting platelet aggregation. It is targeted by medications including abciximab, eptifibatide, and tirofiban. However, GpIIb/IIIa is not found on B-cells, which are responsible for producing IgM and other antibody classes (e.g., IgG, IgE, IgA) after undergoing class switching.  
❌ FOXP3:
Incorrect: FOXP3 is a marker found on regulatory T-cells (Treg). These cells are responsible for ensuring self-tolerance and, in turn, help reduce the risk of autoimmune diseases. In contrast, this researcher most likely isolated a B-cell, which would not express FOXP3.  
❌ CD8:
Incorrect: This researcher most likely identified a B-cell. After being activated, B-cells produce IgM but can subsequently undergo class switching to produce other antibody classes (e.g., IgG, IgE, IgA). In contrast, CD8 is expressed on T-cells but not on B-cells.  
❌ CD28:
Incorrect: CD28 is a surface protein found on T-cells. It interacts with B7 on antigen-presenting cells and contributes to T-cell activation. In contrast, this researcher most likely isolated a B-cell, which would not express CD28.

questions.text: A researcher isolates an immune cell from a blood sample. This cell stimulates eosinophils and mast cells. It also promotes B-cell class switching so that they produce IgE. Which of the following surface proteins is most likely expressed by this cell?
questions.solution:
The researcher most likely identified a Th2 T-cell. This cell type helps fight parasitic infections by stimulating mast cells and eosinophils and promoting B-cell class switching, so they produce IgE. Th2 cells (and all T-cells, for that matter) express the CD28 surface protein.   

Different immune cells can be distinguished based on their surface proteins. A comparison of the proteins expressed by each cell type can be found below.  



Option Analysis

❌ Major histocompatibility complex type I :
Incorrect: Major histocompatibility complex class I (MHC I) proteins help present fragments of exogenous antigens to CD8+ T-cells. MHC I molecules are found on antigen-presenting cells. While antigen-presenting cells play an important role in activating the immune response, they are not directly involved in either class switching to IgE or stimulation of mast cells and eosinophils.  
❌ B7:
Incorrect: B7 is a ligand found on the surface of antigen-presenting cells. Interaction between B7 and CD28 (found on T-cells) is one of the signals required for T-cell activation. However, antigen-presenting cells are not directly involved in either class switching to IgE or stimulation of mast cells and eosinophils.  
❌ CD19 :
Incorrect: CD19 is found primarily on B-cells. This surface protein plays an important role in B-cell survival and maturation. In contrast, this researcher most likely isolated a Th2 T-cell, which promotes B-cell class switching to IgE and stimulates mast cells and eosinophils.  
❌ CD8:
Incorrect: This researcher most likely identified a Th2 T-cell, which is derived from CD4+ T-cells. As a result, Th2 cells would not express the CD8 surface protein.  
✅ CD28:
Correct: See Main Explanation.

questions.text: A biologist isolates an immune cell from a blood sample. This cell’s primary function is to fight intracellular pathogens. It contains CD3, CD4, and CD40 surface proteins and stimulates macrophages and cytotoxic T-cells. Which of the following cells was most likely isolated?
questions.solution:
This biologist most likely isolated a subtype of T helper cell called the type 1 helper (Th1) T-cell.  

T helper cells interact with and stimulate other immune cells. In addition to Th1 cells, different types of T helper cells include type 2 helper (Th2), type 17 helper (Th17), and T follicular helper (TFH) cells. There is another group of T-cells called T regulatory (Treg) cells. However, they are not considered helper T-cells since they are primarily involved in the contraction and regulation of the immune response.  

Th1 cells help the body fight intracellular pathogens by producing interferon-gamma, which stimulates macrophages to kill ingested pathogens and producing IL-2, which stimulates cytotoxic T-cells and natural killer cells.  

Th2 T-cells stimulate mast cells, basophils, and eosinophils and induce immunoglobulin class switching to IgE. Th2 cells are essential in fighting parasitic infections.  

Th17 T-cells help regulate tissue inflammation, activate neutrophils, and fight extracellular infections.  

T follicular helper (TFH) cells assist in B-cell maturation and differentiation. They also promote the formation of memory B-cells.  

Finally, regulatory T-cells (Treg) are responsible for ensuring self-tolerance and help reduce the risk of autoimmune diseases.  



Option Analysis

✅ Type 1 helper T-cell:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Type 2 helper T-cell  :
Incorrect: Type 2 helper (Th2) T-cells stimulate mast cells, basophils, and eosinophils. They also induce immunoglobulin class switching to IgE. Th2 cells are essential in fighting parasitic infections. In contrast, Th2 cells do not typically play a significant role in stimulating macrophages and cytotoxic T-cells or fighting intracellular pathogens.  
❌ Regulatory T-cell  :
Incorrect: Regulatory T-cells (Treg) are responsible for ensuring self-tolerance and, in turn, help reduce the risk of autoimmune diseases. In contrast, Treg cells are not typically involved in fighting intracellular pathogens.  
❌ T follicular helper cell  :
Incorrect: T follicular helper (TFH) cells assist in B-cell maturation and differentiation. They also promote the formation of memory B-cells. However, they do not play a significant role in stimulating macrophages and cytotoxic T-cells or fighting intracellular pathogens.  
❌ Natural killer cells  :
Incorrect: Natural killer cells are part of the innate immune system. They can release perforins and granzymes to induce apoptosis in tumor or virally infected cells. However, since they are not derived from CD4+ T-cells, natural killer cells would not express the CD4+ surface protein.

questions.text: A B-cell is activated after an antigen causes its surface receptors to crosslink. This B-cell subsequently uses its MHC molecule to present a fragment of the antigen to a nearby helper T-cell. The MHC-antigen complex and CD40 protein on the B-cell’s surface successfully interact with the T-cell receptor and CD40L. Which of the following changes will most likely occur to this B-cell?
questions.solution:
The B-cell in this vignette has been activated by an antigen and later stimulated by a T-cell. As a result, the B-cell will likely undergo class switching and produce non-IgM antibodies.  

B-cells are produced and mature in the bone marrow, where they undergo VDJ recombination to produce different types of B-cell receptors (BCRs). Afterward, B-cells leave and travel to secondary lymphoid organs (e.g., spleen, lymph nodes).  

B-cells are exposed to antigens in these lymphoid organs and can be activated in one of two ways. First, the B-cell can be activated if an antigen binds and causes crosslinking BCRs. Alternatively, if the complement C3d has attached to the antigen, it can activate a B-cell by binding to the BCR and CD21 protein (which binds with C3d).  

An activated B-cell then differentiates into a plasma cell that secretes only IgM. If an activated CD4+ T-cell is present, it can help the B-cell undergo class switching. Since B-cells are a type of antigen-presenting cell, they will present the antigen on an MHC class II molecule to the nearby CD4+ T-cell. Once the T-cell is activated, it will express CD40L, which binds to CD40 on the B-cell. These changes prompt the B-cell to express cytokine receptors and T-cell to secrete cytokines (e.g., IL-4, IL-5), thereby enabling class switching and production of non-IgM antibodies (e.g., IgG, IgE, IgA).



Option Analysis

❌ Increased production of pentameric antibodies  :
Incorrect: IgM antibodies have a pentameric structure. B-cells initially produce IgM after being activated by an antigen. However, B-cells will undergo class switching after being stimulated by a T-cell and stop producing IgM.
✅ Initiation of IgG production:
Correct: See Main Explanation.   
❌ Release of perforins  :
Incorrect: Perforins are proteins released by cytotoxic T-cells and natural killer cells. The perforins bind to the target cell and cause the formation of pores in the cellular membrane. Granzymes can pass through these pores and induce apoptosis of the target cell. In contrast, perforins are not released by B-cells.  
❌ Increased release of IL-10  :
Incorrect: Interleukin 10 (IL-10) is released by T-cells and causes downregulation of the immune response. In contrast, IL-10 is not typically produced by B-cells.  
❌ Upregulation of interferon-gamma production   :
Incorrect: Interferon-gamma (IFNγ) can be produced by T-cells and natural killer cells. Its effects are multifold and include stimulating macrophages to kill phagocytosed organisms, promoting granuloma formation, and increasing cellular expression of MHC molecules. In contrast, IFNγ is not routinely released by B-cells after being activated by T-cells.

questions.text:
A 29-year-old woman comes to the office with joint pain and fatigue. For the past three months, she has felt excessive fatigue with normal activity, associated with poor appetite, and a 5 lb (2.3 kg) weight loss. The joint pain is characterized by stiffness in her fingers and wrists that lasts an hour after waking up and usually improves throughout the day. She has no significant past medical history. The patient’s temperature is 38.0°C (100.4°F), pulse is 77/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 115/76 mmHg. She appears tired. Physical examination shows symmetrically swollen and tender wrists bilaterally, and abdominal examination shows splenomegaly. Examination of the patient’s face is shown below:


Reproduced from: Wikimedia commons    

Follow-up laboratory studies show the following:  
 
Laboratory value  Result 
 Hemoglobin  9.0 g/dL 
 Leukocyte count  3,800/mm3 
 Platelet count  125,000/mm3 
Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient’s laboratory findings?
questions.solution:
This patient is presenting with systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) based on the systemic features of fatigue, weight loss, and fever; the presence of inflammatory arthritis; and the photosensitive malar rash (flat, fixed erythema over the malar eminences, with sparing of the nasolabial folds).  

SLE results from a combination of predisposing factors causing an abnormal immune response leading to autoantibody immune complex deposition, inflammation, and end-organ damage. Pathogenesis begins when environmental triggers cause cell damage and apoptosis, exposing nuclear material to the immune system. Genetic susceptibility can lead to poor clearance of these nuclear antigens and to the recognition of their moieties as foreign. Dendritic cells present these antigens to B-cells which then produce autoimmune antibodies, known as antinuclear antibodies (ANA). These antibodies spread through the bloodstream, forming immune complexes with antigens encountered in the blood, and deposit within various organs. There, these immune complexes cause complement cascade activation, leading to enzyme-mediated cell damage, referred to as a type III hypersensitivity reaction. End-organ damage (e.g., rash, nephritis, synovitis) occurs as a result.  

In addition, non-complexed auto-antibodies can directly bind to antigens recognized on the cell membranes of circulating hematologic cells, activating the complement pathway on the cell surface and causing cellular destruction. This type II hypersensitivity reaction causes the hematologic manifestation of SLE, including anemia (usually chronic, less often hemolytic), leukopenia (specifically lymphopenia), and thrombocytopenia (rarely less than 50,000/mm3). Processing of these antibody-covered cells may lead to lymphadenopathy and splenomegaly. Although most patients with SLE will have one or two cytopenias, they can also have pancytopenia, as in this patient.  

 

Option Analysis

❌ Type I hypersensitivity reaction:
Incorrect: Type I hypersensitivity reactions are caused by antigenic cross linking of IgE on mast cells and basophils, causing the release of vasoactive biomolecules and the immediate allergic or anaphylactic response. SLE is not associated with Type I hypersensitivity reactions.
✅ Type II hypersensitivity reaction:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Type III hypersensitivity reaction:
Incorrect: Type III hypersensitivity reactions occur when antibodies (IgG) bind to soluble antigens, forming circulating immune complexes that deposit and cause a local inflammatory reaction. Although this is the primary mechanism of organ damage in SLE, it is not the mechanism of blood cell destruction in SLE, and therefore it does not explain this patient’s laboratory values.  
❌ Type IV hypersensitivity reaction:
Incorrect: Type IV hypersensitivity reactions occur when T helper cells are activated by antigen presenting cells, developing memory and causing macrophage activation and inflammation when that antigen is encountered again. This is not a primary reaction caused by SLE.  
❌ Type V hypersensitivity reaction:
Incorrect: Type V hypersensitivity reaction is sometimes used to describe activating antibody presence (e.g. Graves disease), but the concept is not generally accepted as a true hypersensitivity reaction.
